description.narrative: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs Strategic Plan 2019-2022

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

provider-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands
Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands
Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: Greater impact through new programmes and bigger anchoring in local realities through country and field offices

description.narrative: Developing new programmes allows Interpeace to have a greater impact in fulfilling the first part of its mandate, namely to strengthen the capacities of societies to manage conflict in non-violent, non-coercive ways, by assisting national actors in their efforts to develop social and political cohesion. The core funding by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs that Interpeace receives is an essential contribution to programme development, which is dependent upon the organization having the financial freedom to explore if its approach could add value in new contexts. This often leads to leveraging of further funds to support the newly developed programmes, thus multiplying the impact of the seed investment made possible through core funding. Developing new programme work also contributes to attaining the overall goal of the Dutch Security and Rule of Law Division (SRoL) Theory of Change to “enhance ‘legitimate’ stability and sustainable peace in fragile contexts in order to achieve sustainable development”. The oepning of new country and field offices contributes to these objectives.

title.narrative: Development of new country programmes in Burkina Faso and Morrocco

comment.narrative: Expanding the scope and reach of Interpeace programmes allows the organization to have more impact in preventing violence and building peace, notably in new and emerging conflict situations. Developing programmes in fragile countries in an agile yet carefully calibrated manner enables Interpeace to contribute to reducing violence and enhancing security, as well as increasing inclusion and resilience. This can create the conditions for sustainable development at the heart of the Security and Rule of Law Division (SRoL) Theory of Change. In 2018, Interpeace undertook programme development in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burkina Faso, and Tunisia.

title.narrative: New field offices opened in the Demoratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and new country office in Burkina Faso

description.narrative: Description: # of new field or country offices

title.narrative: Development and soft launch of the Principles for Inclusive Peace

description.narrative: In November 2019, Interpeace soft launched at the Paris Peace Forum an initiative called the “Principles for Inclusive Peace” which commenced a two-year global process of bottom-up and top-down research, consultation and political advocacy to review and develop commonly agreed guiding, non-binding international norms and standards for peace processes. The process will be led by an international commission of eminent political leaders, scholars, civil society leaders and practitioners with knowledge and experience of peace processes.

title.narrative: The initiative was selected from over 700 projects to be one of ten scale-up projects by the Paris Peace Forum for commencement in 2020.

description.narrative: # of projects awarded at the Paris Peace Forum 2019

Developing programmes in fragile countries in an agile yet carefully calibrated manner enables Interpeace to contribute to reducing violence and enhancing security, as well as increasing inclusion and resilience. title.narrative: Institutional systems refined to maximize accountability and efficiency

description.narrative: Institutional systems are refined to maximize accountability, efficiency and reporting. Enhanced accountability, efficiency and reporting are key to create the transparency and trust required to engage in effective, long-term peacebuilding. We are committed to efficiency and transparency to ensure the best use of resources towards our institutional objectives and impact goals. Having modern, agile and efficient institutional systems in place, enhances Interpeace’s ability to carry out its peacebuilding work.

title.narrative: Operationalise peacebuilding approaches in development and humanitarian work, called Peace Responsiveness

description.narrative: Interpeace is engaging in formal and informal partnerships with UN agencies to conribute to making their work more peace responsive, hence helping to improve the efficacy of their technical development and humanitarian work in a variety of sectors (food, health, WASH, education etc.) and for them to be more explicit and intentional about the peace outocmes of their interventions.

title.narrative: Improved monitoring and evaluation and reporting mechanisms for the benefit of Intepreace and its donors

description.narrative: The reporting in the 2019 strategic partnership report to the Netherlands has for the first time been based on the organization-wide Change Framework and the Dutch Security and Rule of Law Results Framework, which allows both Interpeace and the Dutch government to more effectively demonstrate the results based on a variety of qualitative and quatitative indicators. This further enables staff to design and implement activities utilizing clearly defined effective pathways of change to attain Interpeace's three underlying impact goals: 1) Reduced Violence and Enhanced Security; 2) More Inclusion and Increased Resilience; 3) Systemic Progress in Peacebuilding Influence and Practice.

title.narrative: Change Framework mainstreamed as a basis for reporting to the Netherlands and other donors

description.narrative: # of strategic partnership reports submitted based on Change Framework and quantitative indicators

comment.narrative:
Interpeace developed an organization-wide change framework through a participatory process in 2018. As a first step towards ensuring all of the organization’s programmes and initiatives are designed and implemented in pursuit of the identified institutional objectives and impact goals, a process was subsequently undertaken to closely familiarize all staff with the Change Framework and its implications for their work.
The framework is reflected in the 2019 workplan for the organization. The framework in place now also allows Interpeace to speak with one voice and more effectively contribute to the shared goal of sustainable peace.
